featured_projects.headline: Welcome to GESIS Notebooks
featured_projects.description: GESIS Notebooks is an online service for researchers in the Social Sciences to publish and execute data-driven research designs.

featured_projects.headline: Scientometrics Summer School
featured_projects.where: Centre for Science and Technology Studies, Leiden University
featured_projects.description: In these Notebooks, you will learn how to perform scientometric network analysis.

featured_projects.headline: Analytical Information Systems
featured_projects.description: Learn about the use of programming for data analysis, data management, and statistical analysis techniques.

featured_projects.headline: Meta-Analysis in Social Research
featured_projects.description: Introduction to Systematic Reviews in International Development, Mannheim, Germany | December 11th-12th, 2019

featured_projects.headline: GESIS DataDay 2020
featured_projects.who: Fabian Flöck, Johannes Breuer and Arnim Bleier

featured_projects.headline: Homophilic Networks
featured_projects.description: Generate social networks from preferential attachment and homophily and explore parameter effects.

Question 1.Question: Who can use this service?
Question 1.Answer: This service is intended for use by social scientists. You can build and launch all binder-ready projects without logging in. If you want to have more persistent projects, you need to log in.

Question 2.Question: Is the service free?
Question 2.Answer: The service is free for social scientists. In the future GESIS may include a premium offer with additional features.

Question 3.Question: What languages/environments can be on the service? Can I use my preferred R, Julia or Python environment?
Question 3.Answer: You can select any language/environment available from our gallery of more than 5000 binder-ready projects. The gallery contains projects from the MyBinder.org Events Archive.

Question 4.Question: What are the service's restrictions?
Question 4.Answer:
For the anonymous use of via Binder, the service has a limit of:
  • 4 GB memory
  • 2 CPU cores
  • 10 minutes inactivity timeout
For authenticated users, the service has a limit of:
  • 32 GB memory
  • 2 CPU cores
  • 40 minutes inactivity timeout
  • a maximum of 10 GB of persistent disk space
Usage rights are limited to academic activities and governed by our Terms of Use.

Question 5.Question: I have a question or have found a bug. Where can I open up an Issue?
Question 5.Answer:
For questions regarding Jupyter or the Binder import, join the discussion, read the docs or see the code. Please open an issue on our GitHub repository for questions regarding GESIS Notebooks. We are looking forward to hearing from you.
If possible, please include:
  • a short description
  • steps necessary to reproduce the problem
  • a screenshot of the issue

Question 6.Question: Can I host my own version of this platform?
Question 6.Answer: The project is open-source and the code is available at https://github.com/gesiscss/orc.

Question 7.Question: Where can I create a JupyterHub API token?
Question 7.Answer: You can use token request page to create a JupyterHub API token. You can also read more about the JupyterHub API in the JupyterHub docs, how to make an API request and the different ways you can use the API.

Question 8.Question: How can I export my data?
Question 8.Answer:
1. Launch gh/gesiscss/data_science_image and start a terminal
  2. Run zip -r ~/myprojects.zip /projects/* in the terminal
  3. Go to the Notebook dashboard, select myprojects.zip file and download

Question 1.Question: What is Binder?
Question 1.Answer: Binder is an open-source project that enables the creation of shareable, interactive, reproducible scientific analysis environments. You can read more about Binder here.

Question 2.Question: How can I manage my projects?
Question 2.Answer:
After launching a new repository, it will appear in Your Projects:
  1. Concurrently store up to 5 projects
  2. Control the projects you are currently working on
  3. Directly link to the project repositories

Question 3.Question: Where can I find binder-ready projects?
Question 3.Answer: The Binder Federation maintains a machine readable archive of projects that are binder-ready and suited for the import in GESIS Notebooks. A gallery for you to browse is available at https://notebooks.gesis.org/gallery/.

Question 4.Question: How can I make my Notebooks binder-ready?
Question 4.Answer: For more information about making a Notebook binder-ready, take a look at the binder user guide.

Question 5.Question: How can I create a direct launch link for my notebooks?
Question 5.Answer: Just like mybinder.org, you can create a direct launch link for a notebook repository. To launch the notebook without persistence (no login required) you can create a URL like https://notebooks.gesis.org/binder/v2/gh/github_account_name/repository_name/HEAD with appropriate 'github_account_name' and 'repository_name'. To launch this with persistence (login required) you can construct a URL with https://notebooks.gesis.org/services/binder/v2/gh/github_account_name/repository_name/HEAD.
